bboxes.raw_text:
SAN FRANCISCO - NAACP
will challenge the constitution
atty of California S new housing
law prohibiting any public agency
in the state from imposing ban
on discrimination in the sale or
rental of residential property,
Mrs. Tarea Hall Pittman, NAACP
West Goa st regional director,
announced.


The non-discrimination ban,
Proposition IA, was approved by
voters on Nov. 8.


1t amended the state constitu-
tion with this key provision:
"Neighter the state nor any sub
division or agency thereof shall
deny, limit or abridge, directly or
indirectly, the right of any person
who is willing or desires to sell,
lea Sc or rent any part or all of
his property, to decline to sell,
lea Sc or rent such property to
such person or persons as he,
in his absolute discretion,
chooses"


Mrs. Pittman stated that lit is
the intentin of the NAACP to test
the constitutionality of PROPOSE
tion IA as quickly as the neces-
sary papers can be prepared"


AS a preliminary step, NAACP
attorney Nathaniel S. Colley will
represent Frank Canson, former
NAACP Sacramento branch
president, in a test case which
will seek to halt the printing of
the new mea sure in the State Con-
stitution.


Since the pa ssing of the propo-
sition, William l.. Slayton, COM
missioner of the Urban Renewal
Administration, has called tenn
porary halt to the approval of any
more Federal financing for urban
renewal programs.

Post office insignias showing
riders on horseback will be
switched so the action will appear
to be moving forward.


The department has ordered
more than 200, 900 new emblems.
Personnel will wear the forward
look starting Feb. l..


The post rider is the symbol
of postal service. repre- senting
the delivery by horseback of
letters for many years.

Elizabeth Mckinney of Chica-
go. happily displays her claim
to fortunel Showing her winning
West Indies Sweepstakes-Hos-
pital ticket in one hand, and the
telegram that brought her the
good news. She is guaranteed
at lea st 81 900, with a chance to
win larger prize up to
Sis 900, largest first prize in
the world! The preliminary
drawing was held October 10th
in Barbados, w. l. Ticket draw
ings for huge sweepstakes will
be ba sed on the Santa Anita Ma
turity, to be held January 9th
in Arcadia, California. Ticket
sales close December 5th. Miss
Mckinney works for the Spiegel
mail order firm in Chicago, and
this is the first sweepstakes
ticket she has ever purcha sedl

TEMPE The annual banquet
honoring the footballteam at Ari-
iona State University will be
held Dec. p, $50 pm. in the
Memorial Union Ballroom on the
Sun Devil campus. Admission is
$3.50 per person. Tickets may
be obtained by calling Frank
Rispoli, assistant athletic di-
rector at ASH, o66-338l.

George shington' S presi-
Dental salary $4,000 was 357
times greater than that of bod
carriers and mortar mixers
working on public buildings in
the Capitol area. Today the
President receives 100000
about Is times the pay of COM
parable building laborers work
ing full-time in the District of
Columbia.


* i


Modern homemakers are re-
discovering the honey art of
bread baking. Did you know
that Egyptian cooks b gan
making yeast breads almost
1000 years ago? A baker for
the royal household accidental
ly left some bread dough I'M
tt e n d e d overnight. It fer
mented and rose. Undaunted-
the punishment for culinary
error in those days was a be-
heading = the little baker went
ahead and baked the dough. All
ended happily after delighted
king tasted the bread and COM
mended the baker for his "king-
ly" loaf of bread.

working committee members and the chairman
Chapter Alpha Chi P Omega met Monday to
report progress of sales and related business


the second Phoenix appearance OF the
known hon Fair Wed Dec Phoenix Union
High School auditorium


Terri Springer Ebony Fashion Fair model headlines the
models will fashion original designs in Spanish mood

Murray Lebera Ray Christine Tapp Maple L. Pratt
sleus Johnnie Mae Jackson ticket chairman dea SouDe
and Delois Moore.
